sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Reports letter from Weisse regarding publication by the Mannes Music School of Urlinie-Tafeln; the letter encloses a [Weisse-Kolodin] interview and asks Salzer to translate it when they next meet; Schenker likes the expression "Ear-line."

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Salzer, dated April 19, 1932

tei:transcription.tei:p: Gestern ist ein sehr ausführlicher Brief des lieben Hans W. Click on Hans Weisse. Weisse's letter, which is not known to survive, had been sent from New York, where Weisse (who had left Vienna in 1931) was teaching at the David Mannes Music School. eingetroffen, der ^um^ die Urlinie-Tafeln für die Manes-Schule Click on Mannes Music School. wirbt; sie sollen als „Publikationen der M. Schule" herauskommen. The publication appeared in the summer of 1932 as Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln/Five Analyses in Sketchform with the imprint "Published by the David Mannes Music School, New York." Schenker's "seminar"--composed of Weisse's former students (Salzer, Trude Kral, Greta Kraus, and Manfred Willfort)--that was formed in the fall of 1931 had been working on the analyses to be included in the publication. Herr Manes legt mich auch schon auf die nächste Lieferung gern fest. Schenker clearly intended to prepare further sets of analyses with the seminar. An account of the work of the seminar, including a facsimile of Schenker's list of the works to be studied, is given in Salzer's introduction to the reprint of the Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln as Five Graphic Music Analyses (New York: Dover, 1969), 17-21. The planned second set never came to fruition; on August 2, 1934, Schenker wrote to Jonas about his disappointment at being unable to complete it with the seminar (OJ 5/18, 49).

Dem Bf lag das Interview A one-page clipping of a column headed "Music" that appeared in Arts Weekly March 26, 1932, p. 51. It was written by the music critic Irving Kolodin and was based on a conversation with Weisse. The clipping survives in Schenker's scrapbook (OC2/p. 86); a German translation (translator unidentified) is preserved between pp. 86 and 87. A detailed discussion of the interview is given in David Carson Berry, "Hans Weisse and the Dawn of American Schenkerism," Journal of Musicology 20/1 (Winter 2003), 136-42. bei, darf ich Sie bitten, mir Freitag Schenker saw Salzer every Friday, the day the seminar met in Schenker's apartment. {2} zu sagen, was drin vorgeht. „Ohr-Linie" In his column, Kolodin uses "Ear-line" as a rendering of "Urlinie." Berry (p. 137, fn. 79) suggests that Kolodin, being unfamiliar with Schenker's term, may have thought Weisse was saying "Ohr-linie" when he was in fact saying "Urlinie." gefällt mir nicht übel.
Mit besten Empfehlungen an Sie u. Ihre verehrte Gattin

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Salzer, dated April 19, 1932

tei:translation.tei:p: Yesterday, a very detailed letter arrived from dear Hans Weisse regarding his efforts on behalf of the Urlinie-Tafeln at the Mannes School; they are to be issued as "Publications of the M. School." Mr. Mannes would also like my assurance for the next installment.
Enclosed with the letter was the interview; may I ask you on Friday {2} to tell me what it says. I rather like "Ear-line."
With best regards to you and your dear wife,
